44302521.review:
After playing two full 'cycles', griefing was quite commonplace. Everytime, the game mechanics offered me no real countermove besides shooting my own faction (and thus being penalized, for defending myself!). Losing factions tend to become inactive. So I've experienced several times how my own faction was in fact the most dangerous enemy and my own base the most dangerous place in the game. I was elder in both games too. If you're wondering wether that gave me more options, you obviously don't know where this review is going. The outcast system is entirely toothless. The team damage mechanics are easily gamed and exploited in favor of the griefer, even without making more accounts or calling in fellow trolls.

Why is there team damage inside the faction base at all? Shields are up, the enemy cannot attack, why is it even an option for 'allies'? 

Likewise, why are there three elders? Why does the game assign them, rather than the players? Why do the players assign outcasts, rather than the game? Regulation or agency, pick one.

But the worst part is that these problems are unfixable. All additions so far have turned out to contain loopholes that end up hurting more than they help. The relevant mechanics are poorly conceived at the core and the resulting game is stuck halfway between true regulation and true player agency, ending up with the worst of both worlds: a system that appears to protect you, but is easily exploited and likely to cause you and your faction more damage and setbacks than if there had been no system at all.

Edit: I forgot, but there's actually one more nail in the coffin of this horrible system: allies will be able to see you through walls even as they kill you. Allowing advanced 'allied' players with crystalline arrows to spawnkill you over and over inside your own base or any clan base you might have available to hide in. You can't see enemies in any similar fashion. So crystalline arrows are considerably more useful for teamkilling than any other application!

This is the extent to which the developer has not anticipated griefing and is helpless to stop it.

43906591.review:
****FULL REVIEW**** ******UPDATED REVIEW AT THE END******

Here is my in-depth review for those who may find it useful:

Pros:
- its different - in a world full of similar games and battle royales, this game is a breath of fresh air
- For an early access game it runs better than most games i've played at launch
- Its got a huge PVE element and huge PVP element
- There are multiple ways you can play this game and that intrigues me. 

Cons:
- Yes there are currently an abundance of  trolls and griefers (will talk more about this shortly)
- There are minor bugs i've found, most have been fixed with a quick restart and never frustrating
- Yes the UI is a bit 'dull' and doesn't have some advanced features, but will talk more on this in a moment. 
- It is a grind heavy game, but that is only a con if you don't enjoy grinding (will talk more shortly as well). 

A bit about me, i'm 25, PC gamer for 10 years and console gamer for a long time too. I don't have a favourite genre of games and enjoy giving everything a try. I've put in about 15 hours into this game so far.

This game for me is amazing, its so addicting. When i first got my hands on this game it was 2300 and i had work at 0700. Me and my partner decided to play for an hour before bed to try it out. We went to bed at 0500......work was bad that day!

So lets talk about some of the Cons, cause if you are reading this review you are probably trying to see if this game is for you, and you are most interested in 'why shouldn't i buy this'

So firstly, trolls and griefers. Yes at this moment in time it is a big issue with this game. I have had random friendlies start shooting me randomly for walking past them, when challenged they gave me a world of abuse in chat. All i could do is just /report them and go on my way. I have also encountered people who are purposely not playing this game as multiplayer and just playing solo, the issue with this is you need to work as a team of 20 upgrading the main base to have a chance of winning. 

Now fair enough to those players, this game came out 3 days ago, not everyone knows how to play this game correctly yet. So the next type of troll is actually members of the game who ARE playing it correctly, shouting and swearing and abusing people in chat for not helping the team, rather than giving helpful advice.

The last bit of trolling i have heard of but not experienced is people making second accounts, making a second char on your enemies team, then getting a butt ton of intel for your team, and also destroying items and bases from the inside. 

YES this issue does need to be resolved. However, i love the fact that is happening. One of my favourite games ever is EVE online which i played for 5 years. What i loved about that was it had a feel of 'Anything goes'. I like the fact that you have to always be on edge with this game. AND TO NOTE, there are ways to get around the trolls. Here are some of the things you can do:

- If you get shot by a team mate, you can attack them back and kill them and not lose rep, so is someone going round killing team members? well group up and keep murdering that numpty till he quits the server...
- If you get a spy dumping items: create a separate base at the back of the main base. In that base have all the main storage boxes for the team. As you speak to and learn to trust the non-spys in your team, give them access to that vault. doesn't it sound fun to have to find spys and eliminate them? Also how fun does it sound to try and be a spy and gain someones trust?
- Got someone being rude in chat? Just report/block/ignore them. The worst thing is to reply back, there is nothing you can say that will stop the barrage of abuse, and if you just ignore them they get bored quick....

So lets talk about the UI. Yes it is a bit simple, and there are a lot of things missing. For example a lot of people are crying for a 'sort' button in the inventory, or a button to quick move items across without having to click and drag. But guys this is an early access game, there will be 'simple' things missing. But that's the beauty of an early access game, rather than just complaining in chat, get an account with the official game forums, give them constructive feedback, and watch as the game slowly becomes better thanks to YOU! 

So yes this game IS Grind heavy. But that isn't a bad thing. It gives me such a feeling of accomplishment to level up a skill, or from grinding mats and making loads of simple bows, now being able to make a awesome one for everyone. If you don't like grind heavy games and you just want to pew pew and kill some people after dropping from a bus and doing some dances, well you know what game to go back to...

Last thing i want to talk about is why i love this game so much. It is a game where you can be what you want to be. Want to just farm resources and build a huge ass base for your team? You can do that. Want to become a master crafter in weapons, armour, cooking etc and then be the main supplier to your team of amazing gear? You can do that. Want to level up your character, go out into the wilderness, kill huge pve monsters and gank enemies trying to farm some wood, harvest their souls as your bounty and contribute to your team winning overall? Hell yeah you can do that. Yes granted, you do need an even split of all these types of roles. If everyone on your team just wants to PVP, you aren't going to have a base and will lose. However, there are so many servers, official and private. Go into several, find a group of people you gel with and crack on!

Overall guys if you have actually read this whole review you are clearly interested in the game. The game is currently £23 and be honest with yourself, you've probably spent more money on a takeaway before. Your clearly interested in it, don't worry about the negative nannys, pick up this game, try it yourself, If you are anything like me you won't regret it.

And worst case scenario if you aren't happy with the game right now, its early access, it will change weekly, in 2 months it may be completely different. 

Hope this has been helpful! From my time in the game i feel pretty knowledgeable so far so any questions just leave a comment ^_^

Fowl_play_gaming

(find me on twitch.tv/fowl_play_gaming for regular streams of this game)

43959635.review:
Before I start, I'll point out that I received this game for free as a partnered alpha tester.

So Rend is a team based survival PvP game, with some cool features, but a lot of dreadful design problems.

Personal progression is separated into 3 different areas: main character level, which unlocks class perks. There are currently 4 classes to choose from. This style of progression lets you unlock perks that give access to spells and quality of life buffs.

Then there are the "skill" trees. If you want to gather more from bushes, you're learning Botany, if you cut a lot of logs, you get woodcutting experience etc. Everty so many levels you get a choice of two perks to lock onto your character. Most of the time the choice is easy to make as one perk is inherently just useless...

The third is ascension perks. Points for this progression seem entirely random. On one character I was ascension 5 by regular level 4, on another I reached level 12 before my first ascension point. Although you can get more points at the end of a game.

Character progression is very grindy, and promotes players taking on specific jobs - no use in all 20 mastering woodcut after all.

To craft more gear, a team needs to work together to research specific areas of progression, and for me this is where most of the problems are.

Even if your team researches something specific, such as bows, then to craft that tier 5 bow, an individual player still needs to craft tiers 1-4 personally. This unfortunately promotes resource waste.

Griefing is far too easy. I will not list things here as I don't want to help spread it. But it's far too easy for players to ruin each other's fun.

Between Reckonings you will rapidly run out of things to do. You spend all of your time fortifying and preparing for the Reckoning. The Reckoning itself is incredibly fun though, everyone's shields are dropped and you're attacked by waves of creatures and then sit with no shielding for an hour. It's quite spooky!

But, the between time is lacking... There needs to be some sort of PvE event that allows a team to trigger a Reckoning at another faction's home. It would let players control PvP events, as full scale raids aren't possible which shields are up.

Finally, possibly one of the biggest issues I have noticed is balance. Not genuine game balance, each team gets the same gear (with a unique resource in their area). The balance issue is in being able to pick a team.

I can pick a server, make a character on one team, check out what they have, delete the character and check out another team.

I can do this until I see who the most powerful group is. And I feel this is happening a lot. On most servers during non-peak times you can see one or two teams heavily outweigh the other.

Do I think Rend was ready to leave Alpha? Not by a long shot.

But it does have a lot of potential. The problem is that it's being held back by some pretty damaging design flaws that are putting a lot of players off. If these were fixed, and more content beyond fortifying was added, this game could be awesome.

Of course, this is just my opinion, but right now I wouldn't personally recommend this game. Wait until it's further along in its development cycle.

44178823.review:
I want to like Rend, I really do. It's exactly the kind of game I would normally enjoy playing. However, it falls way short in many areas and unfortunately a lot of those areas are in the core game design so I don't see much hope for the future.

The first major issue is population. Each server has max 60 pop, 20 per side and anyone else trying to get on is put in a queue. This design obviously has issues. The objective of this game is to get 100k spirits so it's a bit like a race. Now imagine a rowing competition where you have 3 boats; one has 10 players, another one has 5 and the last one has 15 - which one do you think will win? So, if you are serious about winning you're probably going to have to be continuously advertising and recruiting (wow so fun).

Second issue is communism. This game is all about teamwork. You are expected to share everything with a bunch of strangers, including the workload. You can probably see how this might create an unfun experience for casual players. If you just want to build a nice little personal base and contribute absolutely nothing you can expect people to get mad at you. On the other hand if you are a competitive player and want to win you will probably find that not everyone shares your style of play and that can also be very stressful. Just like group projects in the real world right?

Thirdly and perhaps most crucially, this game is basically cookie clicker 2.0. 90% of your time in Rend will be spent doing mundane repetitive clicking tasks. That other 10% is wasted time where you should have been clicking on stuff. The win condition of the game is literally to click on floating blue things 100,000 times! The 2 most important things for faction progress are sparks and spirits. Red sparks = clicking on trees, blue sparks = clicking on ores, yellow sparks = clicking on rocks, purple sparks = clicking on plants. There you have it, thats this game in a nutshell. Oh you thought it was about PvP? Sure you can spend your time running around enemy lands but have fun falling massively behind in research and contributing nothing to the main win condition.

Personally I can live with mundane repetition, many games thrive on that sort of thing. This game however fails to properly create that virtual sense of reward that comes with it. Everything you do is for the benefit of the faction, that is supposed to be your "reward". Thanks Stalin, that makes me feel really good about myself... not.

So there you have it, if you enjoy playing cookie clicker and being forced to share everything with people you hate then this game is for you. If you are a casual player or a competitive player without a big premade group (of robotic people) then I would steer clear of this game.

44336205.review:
Rend is best described as a game full of promise that fails miserably in it's execution. In my 30 years of gaming, this game is absolutely the one I [b]want[/b] to match the description, but it's own core design problems get in the way.

Rend takes elements from the MMO and survival sandbox genres, and tosses them into a competitive team vs team arena with a definitive end-point. It has some of the best attributes of all of its inspirations: leveling, class archetypes, open-world base building, creature taming, PvP, technology trees, and more. It pairs three factions against each other, in a 20v20v20 faction setup that promises to include political maneuvering both globally and within your faction, and ensures that if one side gets too dangerous the other two can keep them in check. It's everything you'd want your typical sandbox survival game to be.

Where it fails is in the execution. Where there should be a complex battle between three balanced factions, instead we see one pre-formed clan absolutely decimating two groups of random strangers. They allow you to choose your faction, without restriction, so clans are populating an entire side with strong organization from the moment a cycle begins. There is no balancing between the factions themselves, so said clan is often paired up against two factions comprised of solo players or small groups with little to no interaction prior to joining the server, and this quickly forces some poor sap into the role of a psuedo guild recruiter as they desperately attempt to get things organized. However, there are no catch-up mechanics, so as soon as your faction falls even a day behind  it's likely you will spend the next 3-4 weeks watching a loss play out in slow motion. Within days this leads to the losing factions abandoning the server out of a complete lack of hope and desire to play, which in turn diminishes the enjoyment for the victor as it they spend the remainder of that cycle grinding out a win with little to no interaction. This is as big a lose-lose scenario as you can find, with neither the winners or the losers getting to enjoy the experience the game describes. 

As I write this review, I am looking at the server selection for all of the official North American West servers. Only two have more than 8 people on total, with the majority sitting at one faction with 2-3 players and the others at 0, and almost all of the servers are less than a week into this cycle. Without a method to balance the factions the population has all but disappeared, and every server feels like a ghost town.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Great graphics
[*]Smooth gameplay
[*]Dynamic experience, with a variety of activities to choose from.
[*]Concept full of potential
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Completely unbalanced teams, allowing for pre-formed groups to compete against groups of strangers and skews the battle almost immediately.
[*]No method of catching up as soon as you are behind, so you have to choose between losing over the course of a few weeks or giving up entirely.
[*]The developers have addressed the future plans for this game as of two days ago, and balancing the factions is not even an agenda item. Little to no hope of this changing any time in the near future.

All-in-all, Rend could be a great game. Right now it's not, because of flaws in the game design when it comes to faction balance. While they haven't addressed this concern yet, if they ever do I would absolutely recommend taking a look.

44536439.review:
250 hours played >500 steam hours logged.  I cannot recommend this game in its current state.  There are too many bugs that take up hours of time due to lost resources, kits, pets, etc..., all for every saga to end with a few people from one faction forced to grind spirits alone just to reward those who quit days or weeks ago with the rewards they didn't earn.

There are dozens of servers with less than 10 people online (all factions combined), this leads to a complete lack of PvP.  This lack of PvP leads to a very boring grindfest with no thrill or adventure.  This is after the largest patches that changed the spirit system, which was meant to encourage PvP.  The huge amount of official servers combined with the enormous amount of private servers leaves the average server population far below the 20 v 20 v 20 cap which means increased grinding and decreased PvP.

The taming system, while potentially better than ARK's, is so imbalanced a single player can skip to end game high level pets with no time investment or skill.  There are numerous taming items that are non-functional, lack any tool tips, and are unnecessary.

The building system is completely limited and only provides square pieces and one triangle so structrue design is boring and small.  The crafting system is extremely complicated with some items such as a bow taking 8 different items from different professions to craft.  This in itself isn't bad, but there are many items that aren't even in the game yet leaving entire professions unable to craft their items.  

The personal crafting stations function magnitudes faster than the faction stations which force players to utilize personal/clan bases instead of the faction.  The lack of control for storage also forces players to avoid the faction base.  A complete lack of faction control leads to an endless stream of trolls with the freedom to grief entire factions with little to no repercussion.

The class system is so imbalanced only one class is viable for PvP (Assassin), only one class is viable for farming(Pathfinder), and the other two classes are useless unless paired with the afformentioned(Shaman/Warlord).  

The research system is also unique but again extremely imbalanced.  On three seperate sagas we managed to unlock the last level of one tree while other trees were still only in the 2nd stage.  The XP and faction rep rewarded is also imbalanced due to this skew, causing those who wish to help their faction to be punished and fall behind.

The server host is abyssmal.  Constant disconnects and lag spikes lead to poor PvP experience, unwarranted deaths from falling into holes or off of map, and frustration. 

Developer response is minimal at best.  After sending 90% of their team to a gaming convention the week they launched, there was no communication regarding numerous game breaking bugs, exploits, and server issues.  

There is no end game content.  No bosses to fight, areas to explore, advantages to be gained, nothing.  

Don't waste your time with this one, at least not until it is out of EA.  The graphics are nice, and the theory is unique and could be fun if they figure out how to implement it.  But as it stands, the current state is boring, buggy, and unpopulated.

47728758.review:
I'm still putting time into this game, I bought it a couple weeks back and I've been playing with friends a lot recently, got about 25 hours in at the time of this review.

[i]Rend[/i] is an open world survival game with RPG elements (you gain levels and skill XP for the things you do which unlock perks to make things more interesting and/or easier) and both PvE and PvP servers.  I don't really care for PvP in survival games, because there's something incredibly un-fun about spending dozens of hours building a base only to have some ****head come along and destroy it for fun.  It's a waste of time.  However, PvE is really fun in my opinion, especially if you play with friends.  Really happy that this game gives you the option.  You can play the game at your own pace, live where you want to, and not have to worry about getting killed by players, just nasty animals. ;P

A lot of people in the reviews keep saying this game is dead or there's only 5 players online and that's just plain untrue.  Every single time I've logged on I've seen a total of probably 30-50+ players just on the PvE servers, not even counting the PvP ones.  Sure, the playerbase is a little bit low, but it's definitely not dead.  Additionally, playing this game solo is definitely possible if you're careful and aware of your surroundings.

PROS:
+Beautiful environments
+You get to choose if you want PvP or PvE
+Unique creatures
+Multiple types of ranged combat
+You can spend LOTS of time in this game exploring, farming mats, killing stuff, building, etc.  Good time-killer.
+Taming
+Playable solo or with friends (but it is easier with friends)
+Quite a bit of crafting and research depth
+Unique leveling/research/skill system
+Boon of the Gods chest drops (ALWAYS grab these)
+Unique and fun buffs/enchantments on gear (makes you huge, makes you small, makes you sprint super fast, etc.)

CONS:
-Still needs optimization work done, probably wouldn't run well on low-end computers (I get 40-80 fps varies wildly with a GTX 1070 even on low settings)
-Seems to have some kind of memory leak after playing for several hours on end, using 13+ GB of RAM is really odd
-The crafting UI and crafting in general have a decently steep learning curve and it takes getting used to
-Some creatures roam in packs which makes playing solo a lot harder (if you're into that)
-Early game is VERY grindy, it will take you 6-8 hours of play time to get your bearings and start being able to do more fun stuff and get fun gear.

In general, I'd recommend this to people that want to play a beautiful survival game with RPG-esque elements that don't mind the things attached to an Early Access game (bugs, optimization issues, etc.).  I really enjoy it, I got several friends into it, and I'd highly recommend you try it if you're willing to cut it a little slack.

[b]OVERALL RATING: 7/10 (would be 9/10 if it was optimized a little better)[/b]

48314779.review:
[h1]My newest addiction.[/h1]
Let me preface this with a short story. My introduction to this game was at an event called PDXLAN. For the first time ever, the LAN party invited indie devs to show off their games. One of these games was Rend. I figured I'd give it a shot, it was a free demo. Plus they were giving out swag. I'll be honest, I mostly just wanted some cool stuff to take home from the LAN party. I sat down at one of the computers, and a dev immediately came over to me and asked me about my background of playing survival games. I told him about my experiences in ARK, and 7 Days to Die. He stood with me while I started playing, and hung out with me to teach me the mechanics of the game. He let me ask some questions about the game and its future, and overall it was a very positive experience that I didn't expect to get. That's what really sparked my interest in the game.

Fast forward to today, about two months later. At the time of this review, I'm at 121.4 hours. I have only one character, level 44, and I play almost every weekend. I play in exploration mode, which is effectively an online PVE mode. I'm not even at end game content yet. I can get into every major zone at this point, but I don't have the best gear in the game, and there are still a lot of challenges that stand before me. Certain zones are usually too dangerous to try and tackle solo. This game begs for you to run around end explore, but it has no problem with smashing your head in if you're playing too casually. 

Any time my brother and I would go to a new area we haven't explored much of, it felt like an expedition. We would spend half an hour to an hour just prepping ourselves with gear, medicine, food, ammunition and other items to ready ourselves. We'd get there, and we would take it very slow. We'd walk, we'd leave torches as markers to find our way back. We'd pick every fight, evaluate it, and either engage or avoid. We'd spend hours in an area. Sometimes it would go well, we'd haul back a huge amount of whatever we were looking for. Sometimes it wouldn't go so well, we'd be running around everywhere, split up from each other and fighting to survive just long enough to escape the terrors we got ourselves stuck in. It was thrilling, and the feeling of taking home a lot of resources, or sometimes new gear made the risk worth it.

Is this game buggy? Yes. Will you encounter some kind of issue or incomplete mechanic? Yes. Is this game worth pushing through these problems? Absolutely. I've never had so much fun in a survival game before. I can play it solo, I can play it with my brother, or our friends. We can all dedicate a night to taking care of our own bases, or ban together on major expeditions. Regardless of what it is I'm doing with my time, I can always find something to do, I can always make an adventure for myself, and I always feel like I'm progressing.

If you're unsure about this game, or if you're starting new, here is my advice. Jump into PVE first. Play by yourself, or with a bud. And don't be afraid to ask questions in chat. A lot of people are actually super helpful in this game with advice. The second thing you need to do is join the Discord server, which is linked to on the main menu of the game. You can directly speak to the developers, ask questions to the community, or report bugs directly to the devs themselves instead of some ticketing system.

This might sound weird. But, Rend isn't really just a game to me anymore. From the very first time I sat down to play at PDXLAN, to checking up on the Discord channel, to giving advice and gear to new players, I've felt like a member of a large community. I did pay for the game, but I don't feel like a consumer. I feel like a contributor to a major project, and it's an amazing feeling. If you enjoyed ARK, 7 Days to Die, Rust, or any survival game? You owe it to yourself to at least try this game.

43858790.review:
[u]** This is a review on the Alpha build before launch. **[/u]

[h1]Summary[h1]
Rend is about building a great base to withstand the reckoning as much as PvP against 2 other factions. You can choose to be either Conclave, Revenant or Order. It is about working together to make sure you win the game and come out victories. The choice is yours. Frostkeep Studios put out a good alpha with a lot of potential to grow.
[h1]Rating (out of 10)[h1]
[list]
[*]Graphics: 8,5
[*]Audio: 7
[*]Story: 5
[*]Content: 8
[*]Controls: 9
[*]Gameplay: 9

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game delivers on the graphics. It is build on the Unreal Engine 4 and you really notice on the environment. From sunrise to sunset. You can see the light coming through the vines and trees just on top of the hill. It goes fluent with the day and night cycle. The creature look good, not HD but good enough. Reason I wont give it a 9 or 10 is because it is not HD or 4K. And for this game it is not needed, it fits just right. The sky is the most beautiful. You see planets in all kinds of shapes and sizes. 

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The music is nice to listen to. It does cut off from time to time through my plays but relaxing.
The audio itself, let it be combat or crafting is what you expect from any game. The sounds are a right fit for what you use. The weapons sound ok. Crafting the same.
The good thing about the ambient sound is that you feel like you are either in a forest or in the swamp. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
You are one of these survivors and you can pick your faction. All around you there are these big stones with glowing glyphs on them you can select. These will show you some lore. That is the most story you get out of the game. It could only spark the warrior inside yourself to want to play the game and wage this war by yourself. You can read the whole story at rendgame.com

[h1]Content[/h]
Before going into [b]crafting[/b], [b]PvP[/b] or [b]PvE[/b] I first want to say that the content you can access is all up to you. This means crafting in particular. If you want to dedicate yourself to 1 thing, like armour crafting, or want to do it all. It is possible! Once you made your character, joined a faction and start your journey you can select classes. There are 4 classes in total and you can only pick 2 of them. Each with their own skills. The nice thing about selecting a class is that you can still switch to another one. So, if you are reading all the skills and you did not invest a point you that is. The points you spend can not be refunded as far as we know. Choose wisely. The classes in this game are Pathfinder, Shaman, Warlord and Assassin. You level your character and can spend points into your specific classes. Level 50 is the maximum level of your character.

You also get ascension points. These points can be earned by doing everything that yields experience in the game. They are infinite and can be spend on getting these extra bonusses in the game like more experience or more carry weight or even getting a new hairstyle for your character. There is even the possibility to get pets/mounts in the game. I have not explored this possibility with the playtime I got but it is looking good. Want a fast mount? Or a beast that carries stuff for you? You can get it here. Playing solo, in a clan or really being part of the faction is all up to you as a player.

[b]Crafting[/b]
Starting off with crafting. It is the most important thing in the game! There is so much! Different kind of weapons ranging from close combat all the way to long range. There is no hand to hand weapons or shields. They were removed and will be introduced later on. There is a lot for armour crafters as well. You can get light armour with a lot of resistances to the environments up to leather armour that is wonderful for PvP. And now for the building. The game gives you 4 basic structures at the start that are in the area where only your own faction can enter. From these buildings you start crafting adventure. One of these four buildings is where you do your research. The good thing about the research system is it is central. With almost everything you do you get sparks. These sparks are used for your research and the whole faction benefits of it. These are some of the things you can make: Armor, weapons, potions, building materials, private crafting benches, boxes, siege tools and much more. There is enough to get your time spend without even going into PvP.

[b]PvP[b]
Welcome to PvP in Rend. This is always a hard thing to balance. But here it worked with all the range combat. Physical weapons are not in the game at the moment and will be added on a later time. You are the PvP god! If you are thinking that there is some good hunting for you if you know where to look. But be warned, you can go everywhere except into the base of your enemy that has these big shields up. Let it be their starting area or a outpost. There is a huge shield up in the starting area that will not allow for anyone except their own faction to enter it. And the closer you get, the weaker your shots will be. Around the starting crafting area there is a roughly 250 meter radius that will give you a debuff and the closer you get the to shield the higher it will be. The higher the number on your debuff the less damage you do. 
So, you got a kill! Or you didn’t… Either way, the person that died drops all that he has on him or her. Make sure you are not bringing anything of value or else the enemy will surely be thanking you for that present you brought.
Outposts are a big thing in the game. An outpost can yield you a couple of sparks. These you can convert yourself when acquired to the research you want to. Taking this outpost will make it your factions. There will be an announcement in the chat when a shield will go down and up again, so prepare. Every person in the vicinity of the crystal will get a box dropped with loot if you manage to claim it. In the box there can be potions, armour or even more sparks.

[b]PvE[b]
PvE is straight forward. Grinding materials by chopping down trees, fighting monsters and surviving. There are several biomes in the game and each and every one of the unique. This is where the game lacks a bit in content. There are no raid bosses, there are no dungeons or cave systems to explore. You will spend your time on the surface and sometimes go into a little cave for mining. Every biome is a different Tier. And you only go in there if you need materials for crafting.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Controls in the game are very basic for movement. The only complaint I would have is that there is no autorun and no crouch. With the distance you travel sometime it can come in handy. Harvesting controls are different though. You use both mouse buttons. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Finally gameplay! After that much reading, or you skipped most of it, we get to the point if the game is fun. Like said before, it depends on you and the people in your faction. This game relies heavily on teamwork if you want to beat the other factions. Yes you can solo here, but wouldn’t you want to make sure your base is defended and win it?
Working together will either make or brake this game for you. It worked for me and the whole faction I am in is working together. People that I never met before and we help each other so much. I could not imagine being in a faction where everyone is doing a solo run, that is not how this game should be played in my opinion.
You won! Or lost. Either way the you start new, fresh and start competing again for the next round. This is not a server reset! You keep only your ascension points.
Game plays fluently and well. Only time with the gameplay that I had a problem was massive framedrops at the outpost. That is about it. For a alpha is runs better then most games I played in the past. 

In the end, would I recommend this game? Yes

If you love PvP in small numbers and love to build and help as a community/faction then that is good.

Alright, so, couple points first and foremost:

Graphics -

Game is beautiful, and runs fairly well. It's early access, so it's expected that some of the models and animations look unfinished and somewhat low quality on occasion. Entirely understandable.

Gameplay -

Awful. Don't get this unless you and at least 4+ other friends are willing to commit to it for long hours and long periods of time. You cannot do anything without a decently sized group of people. The game is extremely grindy, combat is relatively poor, menus are extremely unintuitive and unfriendly to new players and nothing in the game tells you how to do vital things.

Traveling is worse. Starting gear won't be able to get you out of the starter area, because most of the mobs have large aggro distances and will follow you until you die, and they hit like trucks.

Finally, the #1 killer for me is the fact that random players can join your faction, take materials and other things out of the inventories, and jump off the edge of the map to make it disappear forever. Sure, you can kill them, but if you do, you lose reputation with your faction and that hurts you just as much as them stealing the items. But then they can just respawn at the base, and then do it all over again while you gain nothing.

All in all, the game looks beautiful and has a ton of potential, but it is Early Access, and I have high hopes that it will end up better! As the game is now though, it's not good.

43921749.review:
Too many core game mechanics and aspects of the game lead to instability and game crashes. Rend is a game based around the teamwork of the faction, when really it is ONLY based around the teamwork of the faction. If not everyone is on the same page then your faction is doomed to fail. Towards the mid-game the responsibilities of the faction are made thick by the tier system - which is based around research. Research can easily be derailed in this game and throw an entire faction off course.

New players are given WAY too many freedoms when they join the game. There is no way to force obedience or train discipline to the new players within the factions of the game - which is an immediate must given just how reliant the game is on communication and teamwork. No forced roles to cement trust and reliance within the group, If you "turn in souls" every night you basically become the "Elder" or "Captain" - very easy to abuse. New players can steal and troll and grief, and cannot be stopped without taking drastic measures. The game punishes you for killing the trolls, it's almost comical.

Skills are also incredibly unbalanced, classes called "Assassins" and "Shamans" rule the game as of now. Assassins when paired with movement speed can outrun anything. Especially with how unstable the official servers are and how attempting to tame creatures currently force-kicks you from the server instead. Even in the official servers you are consistantly rubber banding regardless of ping - due to heavy desync. As other people have been saying, it's fun till someone starts griefing and intentionally taking faction loot and droping it in the middle of no where or giving it to opposing factions.  Experiencing one of these people now named dantheguy.

Interesting concept just impossible to impliment because of griefers.  If this some how gets fixed I can recommend it but right now I would avoid it till its addressed.  Theres also a gigantic dispairity between factions when you fall behind on that kind of stuff.  Game has devolved in to the other factions being near god like and able to take a group of us out solo.

Losing everything on death is far too punishing when your already behind on research.  Becomes near impossible to catch up if the teams ahead of you really stay on you.  Already having the advantage then they take all your gear and items essentially reseting you to have to go out and craft everything again which makes the disparity grow ever more.  

The ascension concept is kind of self defeating.  It takes quite a while to achieve for your average server.  Were at 2 weeks in and the server is mostly dead now.  The entire covenant faction quit because of a griefer and I'm pretty sure monster hunter pulled away big chunks of the rev and order factions.  Only a hand full of people on during reckoning and only 2-4 people the rest of the time if your lucky.  So now trying to get all thoes spirits is just going to take even longer with so few people.  And with a 72 hour wait once you ascend it's kind of not worth ascending anyway.  The weirdest thing ever having a wait time of 3 days to play another game.  Why this isnt instant or 10 minutes is baffling at best and just really poor game design at worst.  Nothing screams we never actually played out game like a 72 hour wait time to play again lol.

A new system was put in place called the outcast system to deal with griefers that intentionally try to delete mats or other griefie behavior.  All it really seemed to do was let the 3 longest playing players on your faction abuse other people.  Causing more problems than it solves in its current state that they actually had to release new patch notes saying abusing outcast system was banable.  

Also it looks like a lot of the servers not just mine are dying out.  When first starting there were so many near capacity.  Now its single didgits most of the time.  Buy at your own peril as this game may already be death spiraling.

However I would verify that people still play it before hand as it's not looking good right now.  And you may want to shop around for a server for a while and not just pick the first one you see. Which brings me to another point.  Getting kicked for a server restart or a patch or even disconnecting doesnt actually remove you from the game so your toon is still standing there just waiting for an npc or player to come kill him droping all his loot when your not even around to get it back.  I get that this is probably intentional so you cant duck out of pvp by just logging out.  But this is too punishing when its a server reset or patch or even just a legit dc. 43952135.review:
I purchased Rend as someone who spends a lot of time playing Rust, Hunt Showdown, Terraria, and Starbound with my husband and who enjoys fantasy settings, PVP, intricate crafting, and sandbox games given the right context.

TL:DR - The game has loads of potential. This feels new and fresh and I have enjoyed it immensely. HOWEVER, if you aren't sold by what you see in the videos and by streamers like Cohhcarnage, DO NOT buy this YET. Give them a few more months to add and polish. Wishlist it for now :)

Initial Thoughts:
Rend was something I actually marked "Not Interested" for in my Q (I cycle through most of this genre of game without looking closely at them) and then stumbled upon again from an ad while surfing online. I watched a couple of videos and pretty soon was showing my husband and 5 minutes later we both were downloading it.

It's *really* nice to look at. I love the popping colors and "art style". It's good while not being CPU heavy (looking at you Hunt...). I've run it easily from my laptop without any graphical/loading/rendering bugs or issues. In fact the only bugs I've seen pertain to taming animals and a few minor ones in crafting and neither have impacted my progress. I love the dynamic of getting 20 people in team and allowing them to do their own progression while benefitting most from everyone working together. There's an event that happens at intervals (could be 1 a week, could be every day depending on server) called The Reckoning where the shields go down on each of the three player capitals on the map and everyone is sieged by  monsters for 15 min out of an hour. The remaining 45min is left to encourage a major PVP battle between groups. Really fun to prepare for and the Discord went crazy when it started. 

I'm not saying this game is perfect. They have a lot to work on. There's a lot of grinding and there's a lot that really isn't practical or doable by a single player. Mobs that will roflstomp you in one hit unless you have two friends or clanspeople with you who can help drop em. And the battle system itself needs some polish IMO. 

All things said though, I've learned so much and still have so much to learn in the 14ish hours I've played at the time of writing this. I recommend giving it a shot. I'm looking forward to future content patches and fixes, but it's definitely playable and fun right now as it is.

43918340.review:
I would like to talk about the biggest complaint that people seem to have with this game. That is griefing and not really being able to do anything about it. I think a major problem with the way people are handling this is that they aren't understanding the main purpose of their factions base. A faction's base is meant to be a crafting station and a place to deposit your spirits that you get out in the world. It is NOT your personal home where you should be putting valuable loot that you and your friends spent a lot of hours working to get. There is a reason that the final tier of the basic survival crafting tree is the divinity stone, which allows you to claim land as your own. This game doesn't have building in it for no reason, and if you don't want people griefing and taking all your crap, don't leave it in some random chest in the spawn for someone to take. This also doesn't mean you should build a base and never come back, and I think rend did a good job by not allowing people to craft everything in their own personal home. Even strategically speaking having all of your factions loot inside one small square base isn't exactly the best idea. Go out and explore the world, build up something for you and your friends, and you can even make it so that other faction members can't open your door, and then you should be good. Again don't forget to deposit your spirits and fortify your factions base when you can, that is the purpose of this game. Also I know that people aren't just griefing rare loot, but they are throwing out basic ore while it is cooking and everyone else is around. Again this shouldn't be that hard to stop, just actually get to know your faction and communicate. You don't need a mic or have to put up a picture of yourself or anything like that, just type /faction. I was in a server where this one guy kept coming in and throwing out our stuff, and me and a couple other people were constantly telling new factions members to look out for this guy and to let other people know. So when someone saw him come online, there were 3 or 4 people saying in the faction chat, "Hey this guy is throwing out loot and being a loser, watch out." And people would take loot out to prevent him from doing anything and they would just ignore him. If he tried attacking people he would get killed by a few of us, and if no one went out of the way to attack him, then there was nothing for him to do and he probably got bored. Don't feed the trolls and argue with him and attack because that is what losers like that guy want. If you have a friends base to go to, or your own then go there and do something else for a while.

This is one of those games that is either going to be really good, or complete trash. I personally think it will be very good if they stay on the right track, and I believe that over time this game could gain a decent community that works together and helps each other out. But that simply will not happen if people keep allowing griefers to take their stuff and give it to other factions. That will just create toxic players and completely ruin this game. 

At the same time, the system isn't perfect as is. There needs to be even better way to stop griefers, and I think that rend is already on to it with the faction rep system. Maybe the top 3 people in the faction are the leader and 2 officers or something, and they have the ability to initiate a vote kick or something, and they could only allow like people who have a decent amount of rep to vote. After someone is kicked the rest of the faction could then get a pop up saying like should that guy have been kicked and if enough people say no then whoever started the vote loses a lot of rep. And maybe if you lose a certain amount of rep then you lose the ability to ever become a officer type again.
